history.content:
Prof. Sahai's advice for 189 is to take 126 and 127 as well: 126 builds the probability intuition while 127 builds optimization thinking, which both help for 189. Taking 189 and 127 concurrently after taking 126 he said is an okay idea—you'll have to put more work in than if you took 127 before 189—but 126 and 189 concurrently after taking 127 is a bad idea. Ideally you should take 126 and 127 before you take 189, if that doesn't work 126 before and 127 concurrently.

Also if you're intimidated by 126, taking Stat 140 is a less ideal but less difficult alternative.

----------

As a controls/robotics PhD student the course I most regret skipping in undergrad was 126. If you're interested in controls you should try taking some of the graduate controls courses like 221A or 220B. I personally don't think that 123 is that useful for controls specifically (assuming that you've already taken 120 and 128), at least the controls work that I do. 128 + 106A is a good combo and will set you up well for 106B should you choose to take it.

Prof. Sahai's advice for 189 is to take 126 and 127 as well: 126 builds the probability intuition while 127 builds optimization thinking, which both help for 189. Taking 189 and 127 concurrently after taking 126 he said is an okay idea—you'll have to put more work in than if you took 127 before 189—but 126 and 189 concurrently after taking 127 is a bad idea. Ideally you should take 126 and 127 before you take 189, if that doesn't work 126 before and 127 concurrently.

Also if you're intimidated by 126, taking Stat 140 is a less ideal but less difficult alternative.

children.subject: @11703. 106B was the best class I took in my undergrad. I think EE 220B was a very worthwhile class and is a bit easier than most other grad courses. 221A is a very good class, but maybe just take it if/when you go to grad school. I liked 188 a lot.

Could you also explain why you regret skipping 126?
How important is the material in 126 for doing control and robotics?

Probability is super important in control. There's an old adage that if we knew the system state at exactly the current time, we wouldn't need control. A big part of control is deriving controllers that are robust to disturbances, sensor noise, and model uncertainty, and you need to consider probability to do that effectively. Stochastic control and robust control are two major subfields which concentrate on systems with uncertainty. In fact the Kalman filter, which all the ML people use so much, is the solution to the Linear Quadratic Gaussian problem, a fundamental result in stochastic control.

In robotics, any sort of system identification will use a lot of probability, as will any sort of perception (SLAM, state estimation, sensor fusion, etc). There are are also lots of algorithms that involve sampling in robotics, and probability will usually come in when thinking about the best ways to sample.

I personally work in nonlinear systems theory with a bit of optimal control, so I don't use probability every day, but even still I'll often run into problems and have to beg my labmates for help, and I've definitely decided not to pursue interesting research ideas because I don't know enough probability.

126 was definitely not the most important class to take for me (those would be 128, 106B, 220B (actually ME 230A, but I doubt it'll be offered for a long time), and 222) but I definitely miss it.

@VALMIK SHANKER PRABHU
Thank you for your answer.
What other courses would you recommend to take? 
Do you think EECS 149 is a good class to take (for Control and Robotics)?

history.content:
How likely will I survice if I decided to take

EECS 126 + CS 189 + EE 123 + another non-EE project class in spring 2021?

I do not have great interest toward in learning probability, although I know it is critical to take EECS 126.

Moreover, EECS 126 is a very challenging and a very high workload course so I am not sure if I really want to take EECS 126.

Any suggestions?

I think I will take

CS 162 + EECS 149+ EECS 106A +EE C128 in fall 2021. 

Is this a good combo to take?

Any other courses which you would recommend for doing control and robotics?

Thanks in advance
